sen.e: It was built in a structure like a castle in 1650, and is a building called in another name "Yatsumune" (八つ棟) or "Yatsumune-zukuri" (八つ棟造り, complicated roof style with multiple ridges and bargeboards) because of its complicated roofing.

sen.j: 今西家住宅は、棟札と呼ばれる上棟時の年号や施主名や大工棟梁を初めとする施工関係者の名を墨書きした細長い板や、屋根の棟の端部を飾る鬼瓦に刻まれた鬼瓦銘と呼ぶ刻銘によって慶安3年の建立年代が明らかである。
sen.e: It is evident that the Imanishi-ke Jutaku was built in 1650, since there remain a long and narrow plaque called munafuda on which the year when the framework was completed, the name of the client, and the names of the persons concerned with the construction including the master carpenter were written in India ink, and the inscription called onigawara-mei that was inscribed on the onigawara (Japanese gargoyle roof tile) with which the ends of the ridges of the roof were decorated.

It is clear that the Imanishi-ke Jutaku was built in 1650 because of a long and narrow board referred to as munafuda bearing the year when the framework was completed, name of the client and the other people concerned with the construction including the master carpenter written in ink as well as an inscription referred to as onigawara-mei that was carved on the onigawara (Japanese gargoyle roof tile) that are used to decorate the ends of the roof ridges.

sen.e: The magnificent external appearance with okabe (extended large walls) in which pillars are hidden under shikkui (white plaster) is a building structure which makes one associate with a castle architecture rather than a folk dwelling where ordinary people live.

The magnificent exterior with okabe (a style of wall construction) in which posts are hidden under shikkui (white plaster) is a building structure which reminds one of a castle rather than a private residence of ordinary people.

sen.e: These moats are 5.45 meters in width, and the earth generated by construction when these moats were dug up was heaped up to constitute dorui (earthen walls), with the nine gates opened on the north, south, east, and west sides,

The surrounding moat is approximately 5.45 meters in width and the earth dug up during excavation of that moat was piled up to build dorui (earthen walls) which seemed to have a total of nine gates that serviced the north, south, east and west ends of the town.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: このような環濠集落を必要としたことは、中世未明から信奉してきた一向宗への弾圧からの自衛のために町造りの形態がそのまま残されてきたわけである。
sen.e: The reason why the town required to be surrounded by a moat like this is that the form of the town construction was handed down as it was to defend themselves against the oppression of the Ikkoshu sect which the townspeople had believed in since the opening of the Medieval period.
sen.cmt: Excel原稿の「一向宗への石山合戦からの自衛」では「石山合戦」への言及が唐突なので、Web原稿に合わせて「一向宗への弾圧からの自衛」に変更しました。
sen.e: The background of Imai-cho being a village surrounded by a mot goes back to the days when that town was constructed for self-defense against attack by external forces cracking down on the Ikkoshu faith which the townspeople had embraced since before dawn of medieval times and that legacy with respect to the physical layout of the town remains intact today.
sen.cmt: 意味を明瞭にするため英訳を補足してあります。

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 現在の今西家住宅は、1650年建立以前に本陣及び住居が築かれていたことから2度目の普請であるが、前記集落の中の西端にあって、あたかも西の天守閣といった堂々たる風格を現していたと伝えられている。
sen.e: Present-day Imanishi-ke Jutaku was the second building, because before it was built in 1650 a structure for the honjin (headquarters of army) and a dwelling house had already been built, and as it was located at the westernmost position of the town, it has been handed down to now that it appeared to have a stately air as if it were the western tenshukaku (keep or tower).

Since the honjin (headquarters of army) and family quarter had already existed prior to its construction in 1650, the present-day Imanishi-ke Jutaku was built in the second-phase but it has been told that, situated at the westernmost of the above village, it had a commanding air of a castle tower.
sen.cmt: 意味を明瞭にするため原文を補足または重複を省略してあります。
sen.e: Since the honjin (headquarters of army) and family quarter had already existed prior to its construction in 1650, the present-day Imanishi-ke Jutaku was built in the second-phase but it has been told that, situated at the westernmost of the above village, it had a commanding air of a castle tower.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: このようにして今井の町造りが始まり、現在の今井町に変わってきたわけであるが、なぜこのような町造りが必要であったか、または今井町のおいたちなどを述べないと、当時の今西家住宅の存在がわからないと思われるので、それらのことから先に述べることにする。
sen.e: While in this way the town of Imai began to be constructed and it has turned into present-day Imai-cho, because it seems that the significance of existence of the then Imanishi-ke Jutaku cannot be understood, unless it is explained why the town needed to be constructed in this way or what was the history of Imai-cho, we will explain these first.

Town building of Imai thus began and has subsequently undergone changes to become Imai-cho as we know it today but as it seems difficult to understand the significance of Imanishi-ke Jutaku in those days unless some facts such as why it was necessary to develop the town in this fashion and the background of Imai-cho are explained, we will discuss these to begin with.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.e: But Yagi-cho which lies 1.5 kilometers to the northeast of Imai-cho was a footing for traffic bound for Nara, Kyoto, Naniwa, Ise, Yokkaichi, Yoshino, and Kishuji, and so it seems that the neighborhood of Yagi began to develop into machiya in that sense in the early times, and that the business activities also became promoted spontaneously there.

sen.e: At this time, the form of Imai-go was so-called Kango-shuraku, or a village surrounded by moats with dorui heaped, in order to protect the autonomy of the village people against external enemies, and at the present time too, the traces of the moats are left as the remains around Imai.

sen.e: Besides, although the streets in Imai-cho have remained in a comparatively well-ordered state up to now, they are not running straight from end to end through the town, but they bend like a crank in the width of a street at the entrance part, or come to a T-intersection at a short distance from the entrance, so that they are arranged not to allow the inside of the town to be seen through from the outside.

The streets of Imai-cho have remained relatively in good condition today but, instead of running straight across town from one end to the other, they were designed to obstruct views of the town from outside with various features such as sharp turns at the town entrance and T-type intersections near the gate.

sen.e: Therefore, the Tokugawa shogunate acknowledged Imai as an administrative town, set up a so-kaisho (meeting place of self-governed local community) like in Edo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Nara, and came to command machi-yakunin (municipal officials) such as machi-doshiyori (ward heads) to administer the affairs of the town.
